unnormalised: ## Builder Reviews: How important are they, really? (Real Estate & Property)
normalised: ## Builder Reviews: How important are they, really? (Real Estate and Property)

unnormalised: So, you're finally taking the plunge and buying that dream apartment in Bangalore, huh? Congratulations! But before you hand over that hefty booking amount to Purva Landmarks or Sobha Developers, have you done your homework on builder reviews? Seriously, *really* done it?
normalised: So, you're finally taking the plunge and buying that dream apartment in Bangalore, huh? Congratulations! But before you hand over that hefty booking amount to Purva Landmarks or Sobha Developers, have you done your homework on builder reviews? Seriously, really done it?

unnormalised: I've seen too many friends, like Ramesh, get burned after trusting the marketing spiel and glossy brochures. He booked a flat in a seemingly amazing project in Whitefield back in 2018. Promised possession date was 30/06/2020, but he finally got the keys in December 2022! And the finish? Let's just say it wasn't exactly "international standards" as advertised.
normalised: I've seen too many friends, like Ramesh, get burned after trusting the marketing spiel and glossy brochures. He booked a flat in a seemingly amazing project in Whitefield back in two thousand and eighteen. Promised possession date was thirtieth june two thousand and twenty, but he finally got the keys in December two thousand and twenty two! And the finish? Let's just say it wasn't exactly "international standards" as advertised.

unnormalised: Builder reviews are your best friend. Check out sites like NoBroker Forum and CommonFloor to see what actual residents are saying. Look beyond the star ratings; read the detailed comments. Are there constant complaints about delayed possession? Shoddy construction? Poor maintenance after-sales? These are red flags!

unnormalised: Think of it like choosing between two biryani places in Hyderabad. You wouldn't just blindly go to the one with the fanciest signboard, right? You'd ask your friends, check online reviews, maybe even try a small tasting beforehand.
normalised: Think of it like choosing between two biryani places in Hyderabad. You wouldn't just blindly go to the one with the fanciest signboard, right? You'd ask your friends, check online reviews, maybe even try a small tasting beforehand.

unnormalised: Don't just look for recent reviews either. Older reviews can give you a sense of the builder's track record over time. Maybe their earlier projects were great, but they've started cutting corners recently. Also, visit the actual site at around 15:00 hrs on a weekday to get a feel for the construction quality and the neighborhood.
normalised: Don't just look for recent reviews either. Older reviews can give you a sense of the builder's track record over time. Maybe their earlier projects were great, but they've started cutting corners recently. Also, visit the actual site at around three o'clock p m on a weekday to get a feel for the construction quality and the neighborhood.

unnormalised: Remember, a few negative reviews might be disgruntled customers, but a consistent pattern of complaints screams "stay away!". Investing in property is probably the biggest financial decision you'll make. Spend the time to research, read those reviews, and protect your hard-earned Rs.! Good luck! Consider even involving your family pandit – Shubh Aarambh is important on 26/01!
